This looks great to me, thank you!

The build doesn't work for me on Fedora, Lars and I just looked at it and it seems that the use of <outputFile> in the asciidoctor plugin doesn't support modules that write multiple files.

Whether it works or not seems to be dependent on the order that the OS delivers files to the module, for me the output is:

`
[INFO] --- asciidoctor-maven-plugin:2.0.0-RC.1:process-asciidoc (generate-slides) @ navigating-ASF-incubation ---
[INFO] Using 'UTF-8' encoding to copy filtered resources.
[INFO] Copying 0 resource
[INFO] Rendered /home/sliebau/Downloads/apache-training-navigating-ASF-incubation-1.0-incubating/src/main/asciidoc/index.adoc
[WARNING] Duplicated destination found: overwriting file: /home/sliebau/Downloads/apache-training-navigating-ASF-incubation-1.0-incubating/target/generated-slides/index.html
[INFO] Rendered /home/sliebau/Downloads/apache-training-navigating-ASF-incubation-1.0-incubating/src/main/asciidoc/projectstats.adoc
[WARNING] Duplicated destination found: overwriting file: /home/sliebau/Downloads/apache-training-navigating-ASF-incubation-1.0-incubating/target/generated-slides/index.html
[INFO] Rendered /home/sliebau/Downloads/apache-training-navigating-ASF-incubation-1.0-incubating/src/main/asciidoc/aboutme.adoc
[INFO] 
`

So the only slide I get is the about me slide, as it is rendered last and overwrites all other content. For Lars on Mac, index.adoc is the last file rendered, so for him it works.

In short: We have to find a different way than "outputFile" to generate the index.html file. Our idea was to just create it as is and then rename later in the Maven process.

We also need to fix this in the template.

While debugging this I also found the reference to Chris' home directory in the POM is still in there

`svgbob>/Users/christofer.dutz/.cargo/bin/svgbob</svgbob>`

I would suggest another cleanup round on the template and then apply it here.
It would also be great if we could create a parent POM so that we don't have to make improvements to the POM in all the subprojects.

Thanks for that. There's probably no need to install http and copy the template to the web root as the template include a way to build and run the slides like that by doing `mvn jetty:run-exploded` and then viewing  http://127.0.0.1:8080/index.html. In most cases you probably don't need to do that unless you want the timer to work in the speaker notes. (There's probably a security setting you can turn off to get it to work as well).
Have you submitted the SGA yet? This can't be accepted until that is done.
looks good to me.

I tried following this https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16306012/github-pull-request-showing-commits-that-are-already-in-target-branch but it failed because of Github UI issues so I'll resubmit the PR.

It may be that https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator-training.git is out of sync with https://github.com/apache/incubator-training.git. I think Chris run into this a few times on the PLC4X project.

There’s a sync git repos at Apache self-selve [1] I’ll try that.

Justin

Files are missing ASF headers. I assume this is not 3rd party code?

I am doubtful about the need as well, but since we had the discussion on the mailing list I was loath to just let the information surfaced there sink away into obscurity again :)

You are right of course, completely forgot about those, I've added them.

Code in here is written by me in its entirety, with some inspiration from stack overflow.
Um - how much inspriration? A lot of older code there is CC-BY-SA and more recent stuff is MIT. The former is Category X and can't be included, the later has LICENSE implications.

Hi @justinmclean 
feel free to make the change. I'm not used to work with web servers, so I don't know the best practices and I am glad for some improvements.

The SO answer in question is [this one](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35274068/rendering-xml-from-draw-io-as-an-image-using-mxcellrenderer).

Code that I took is [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-training/pull/19/commits/8ac5e13996bb4cdd022af6242aee960627788e60#diff-e6ee7387bc0f9aa6bae0c2a4e12a2a0dR55).

The code looks very similar, identical in places, I agree. Then again I'd argue, that this is API usage, not actual logic that was implemented, so even if I rewrote this myself it would still look almost the same.
Not sure what the rules around these things are..

If you look at a piece of code and rewrite yourself that is still copying as far as the license is concerned. Silly I know but that's how it is. Even API usage is sometime questionable see Oracle vs Android on that :-(

The footer on that page says "user contributions licensed under cc by-sa 3.0 with attribution required."
See also:
https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/12527/do-i-have-to-worry-about-copyright-issues-for-code-posted-on-stack-overflow

They did consider move to a more permissive license (MIT) but it seems that didn't go ahead:
https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/272956/a-new-code-license-the-mit-this-time-with-attribution-required?cb=1

To me that means it's Category X and can't be included in an Apache license package. See:
https://apache.org/legal/resolved.html#cc-by

You ask on legal-discuss if this is OK, but from above I would guess not.

Alternatively you can ask the author permission to use the code, if he gives you permission then that's fine. The code was posted by the co-founder of draw.io and draw.io is under a ALv2 I wouldn't see why he would say no.

Thanks for taking a look @justinmclean !
I think the code in question was actually written by someone else, David just edited the question. 
As the code does not produce perfect results and I wanted to revisit it at a later time anyway I'll withdraw my PR for now and reach out to David about a legal way of rendering these images.

And it turns out you refer to the picture as `training_logo.svg` (with underscore) but called the file `training-logo.svg` with a dash so it shows up empty.

And Chris actually did include instructions on how to build the site here http://training.apache.org/developers/building.html
@lfrancke this looks much better and was tested.  Happy to make any more specific changes.

As I said: I know next to nothing about web design, happy to defer to someone who does.

You can close PRs and start new ones but you can also "reuse" an existing one by just committing more stuff to your existing branch.

So what you'd usually do is fork the project, clone it and then create a branch on your local machine: `git checkout -b TRAINING-16` for example. You'd do your changes, commit them and push them to your fork. `git push` should do the trick usually. Then you create a pull request like you did before and if you just keep on committing to your TRAINING-16 branch all these new changes will automatically appear in the existing pull request

Checked it out and tested the site build, looks good to me know.

Thank you for the contribution, I'm going to merge.
looks good to me - thanks!

In my opinion, if someone genuinely can't figure the puzzles out they should ask for hints or pointers from other Developers, rather than looking up the answers. That way, it also promotes collaboration with others, which is a fundamental of Open Source Software.

I would provide the answers, usually any teaching =material with have a lesson plan, marking guide or similar to help anyone use the resource. This is usually not supplied to the students. Perhaps ROT13 the answers?

@lfrancke @justinmclean Do you need anything else before this can be merged?

I tried it out on a Linux box. It was easy to build (didn't need to install any further dependencies, because Maven was already here), README correctly pointed me to the location of the generated slides.

The current content is stored directly under GitHub. I think it would make sense to move it to a sub folder for the likely case that there will be non workshop material on Git/ GitHub.

There seem to be some dependency notices missing in NOTICE (at least from judging what Maven downloads when I'm trying to build things)? Maybe though my understanding of what exactly goes into NOTICE is dated.

From what I can see all headers are where they should be.

For the octocat logo, I'll volunteer to generate one that's a little less stereotypical than the one I used in the original slides.

Which tooling do you use to create these slides? Is there an easy way for me to help you? Content-wise there's still a lot of stuff that's text-only. But I guess that's the "work in progress" part of the pull request.

Yes would make sense to move it to a sub-directory.

Nothing is missing in NOTICE as it only need to list what is included in a release not as a dependancy. We don't have a release yet but that would be the contents on what's on GitHub.

Re tooling I just used a text editor that has a markdown plug-in that does a decent job. But it was generally copy and paste the the text and mark it up.
PING?
Note while the Pixabay license is not listed as a Category A license it's currently being reviewed and likely to be accepted as Category A. See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LEGAL-479
Assuming lazy consensus and committing this.
Please ignore this other another PR with correct branch name
I'd add a LICENSE and NOTICE file. They can be boiler plate, but I would add something about having permission to use the GitHub image. Having an ASF header on the SVG file would also be a good idea.
This is my first comment on this project. Please excuse my ignorance. Do we have to add Licenses files in each PR?
The license file is in LICENSE or did you mean something else? In general a LICENSE file would already exist when raising a PR. You might have to add an ASF header to any new files in a new PR.
How can i merge this PR? Can I get write access to merge it please?
